(boolean, default: true) True means that the Y position is determined by DispYpos, else by DispAtTopOfDrawstopCol.
(integer 0 - panel width, default: 0) absolute X position
(integer 0 - panel height, default: 0) absolute Y position
(boolean, required if FreeYPlacement is false) If true, the label is displayed above the drawstop, else below.
(integer 1 - number of drawstop columns, required if FreeXPlacement is false) Position label at the specified drawstop column.
(boolean, required if FreeXPlacement is false) If true, move label half of the drawstop to the right.
(color, default: Black) Color for the label text.
(font size, default: normal) Size of the label font
(string, default: empty) Font for the text. Empty means use the group label font of the panel.
(string, default: empty) The text to display on this object
(integer 0 - 15, default: 1) Builtin bitmap set to use. 0 means that the label does not have a background image.
(string, default: use internal bitmap according to DispImageNum) Specify the file name of an image to use as bitmap. If the bitmap contains a mask for transparency, it will be used.
(string, default: empty) File name for a external mask for the bitmap. If empty, no mask is added.
(integer 0 - panel width, default: according to the definitions above) Allow to override X position for label
(integer 0 - panel height, default: according to definitions above) Allow to override Y position for label
(integer 0 - panel width, default: bitmap width) Width of the label. If larger than the bitmap, the bitmap is tiled.
(integer 0 - panel height, default: bitmap height) Height of the label. If larger than the bitmap, the bitmap is tiled.
(integer 0 - bitmap width, default: 0) X position on the bitmap of the left pixel of the label
(integer 0 - bitmap width, default: 0) Y position on the bitmap of the top pixel of the label
(integer 0 - Width, default: 0) relative X of left border of the text rectangle
(integer 0 - Height, default: 0) relative Y of top border of the text rectangle
(integer 0 - Width, default: Width) width of the text rectangle
(integer 0 - Height, default: Height) height of the text rectangle
(integer 0 - text rectangle width, default: TextWidth) If 0, no text is displayed. Otherwise the value specifies the maximum line width used for text breaking.

sect1.title: Image objects
sect1.para: Image objects allow to display an image on a panel. They tile the images, if it is bigger then image size. It has the following attributes:

listitem.para: (string, required) Specifies the file name of an image to use as a bitmap. If the bitmap contains a mask for transparency, it will be used.
(string, default: empty) File name for a external mask for the bitmap. If empty, no mask is added.
(integer 0 - panel width, default: 0) X coordinate of the left side. to override X position for button
(integer 0 - panel height, default: 0) Y coordinate of the left side.
(integer 0 - panel width, default: bitmap width) Width of the button. If larger than the bitmap, the bitmap is tiled.
(integer 0 - panel height, default: bitmap height) Height of the button. If larger than the bitmap, the bitmap is tiled.
(integer 0 - bitmap width, default: 0) X position on the bitmap of the left pixel of the image
(integer 0 - bitmap height, default: 0) Y position on the bitmap of the top pixel of the image

sect1.title: Button objects
sect1.para: Button objects are defined on the main panel. Their section name is based on their function. They share the following common properties:

listitem.para: (string, required) Name of the object. The name may be presented to the user in lists too, therefore it should be descriptive. If a GUI representation requires a shorter name, please override this value locally.
(boolean, default: false) If true, the section also includes the GUI properties for the main panel. Otherwise it is not displayed on the main panel.
(boolean, default: false) If true, off is displayed as on and on as off.
(integer 0 - 127, default: no MIDI event specified) Only used for building the initial configuration during the first load - provided just for HW1 compatibility. DEPRECATED.
(integer 1 - 128, default: no MIDI event specified) Only used for building the initial configuration during the first load - provided just for HW1 compatibility. DEPRECATED.
(integer 0 - 255, default: 0) 0 means no shortcut, else it specifies the key code of the shortcut key.

sect1.para: The GUI properties of button objects are:

listitem.para: (boolean, default: true for divisionals, generals and pistons, else false) True means to display as piston, false as drawstop
(color, default: Dark Red) Color for the label text.
(font size, default: normal) Size of the label font
(string, default: empty) Font for the text. Empty means use the control label font of the panel.
(string, default: Name of the button) Content of the text label. You should edit it, if you need to display a shorter string on the label.
(boolean, default: true) If displayed as a piston and this attribute is false, move it a little bit left. Otherwise ignored.

(integer 1 - type dependent, default: see below) Builtin bitmap set to use. GrandOrgue has 7 for drawstops and 5 for pistons. The default is 3 (piston) or 4 (drawstops) for read-only buttons, otherwise the default is 1.
(button row, default: 1) If displayed as piston, it contains the button row according to the layout model. Otherwise ignored.
(button column, default: 1) If displayed as piston, it contains the button column according to the layout model. Otherwise ignored.
(drawstop row, default: 1) If displayed as drawstop, it contains the drawstop row according to the layout model. Otherwise ignored.
(drawstop column, default: 1) If displayed as drawstop, it contains the drawstop column according to the layout model. Otherwise ignored.
(string, default: use internal bitmap according to DispImageNum) Specify the file name of an image to use as on bitmap. If the bitmap contains a mask for transparency, it will be used.

(string, default: use internal bitmap according to DispImageNum) Specify the file name of an image to use as off bitmap. If the bitmap contains a mask for transparency, it will be used. The size must match the on bitmap.
(string, default: empty) File name for a external mask for the on bitmap. If empty, no mask is added.
(string, default: value of MaskOn) File name for a external mask for the off bitmap. If empty, no mask is added.
(integer 0 - panel width, default: according to layout model) Allow to override X position for button
(integer 0 - panel height, default: according to layout model) Allow to override Y position for button
(integer 0 - panel width, default: bitmap width) Width of the button. If larger than the bitmap, the bitmap is tiled.
(integer 0 - panel height, default: bitmap height) Height of the button. If larger than the bitmap, the bitmap is tiled.
(integer 0 - bitmap width, default: 0) X position on the bitmap of the left pixel of the button
(integer 0 - bitmap width, default: 0) Y position on the bitmap of the top pixel of the button
(integer 0 - Width, default: 0) relative X of left border of the mouse rectangle
(integer 0 - Height, default: 0) relative Y of top border of the mouse rectangle
(integer 0 - Width, default: Width) width of the mouse rectangle
(integer 0 - Height, default: Height) height of the mouse rectangle

(integer 0 - max(MouseRectHeight, MouseRectWidth), default: min(MouseRectHeight, MouseRectWidth) / 2) If 0, the mouse events are captured inside the mouse rectangle. Otherwise they must be inside a circle of the specified size too.
(integer 0 - Height, default: 1) relative X of left border of the text rectangle
(integer 0 - Height, default: 1) relative Y of top border of the text rectangle
(integer 0 - Width, default: Width) width of the text rectangle
(integer 0 - Height, default: Height) height of the text rectangle
(integer 0 - text rectangle width, default: slightly smaller than TextWidth) If 0, no text is displayed. Otherwise the value specifies the maximum line width used for text breaking.

sect1.para: Inside the button, the on/off bitmap (depending on the button state) is tiled. If a text width is set, a text label is displayed on it. Mouse events are only captured inside the mouse rectangle.

sect1.title: Drawstop objects
sect1.para: Drawstop objects are buttons with toggle functions. They contain these additional non-GUI properties:

listitem.para: (enumeration, default: Input) Logical function of the drawstop. If the value is Input, it is a normal user controllable drawstop and has no input switches. Not has one only input and negates the state of the input switch. And, Xor, Nand, Nor as well as Or has a variable number of inputs.
(integer 1 - switch count, required if the logical function allows a variable number number of inputs) Contains the number of input ports. Switch999 contains the referenced switches.

(integer 1 - switch count, required) Lists the input switches of the logical function of the drawstop. If the drawstop is a switch, it can only reference switches with a lower number. The number of this settings depends on the function.
(boolean, required) State of the button after loading.
(integer -1 - 1, default: implementation defined) State of the button after pressing GC. -1 means no change, 0 off and 1 on.
(boolean, default: dependent on various settings) Determines, if the button should be stored in divisionals without FULL.
(boolean, default: dependent on various settings) Determines, if the button should be stored in generals without FULL.

sect1.title: Coupler objects
sect1.para: Couplers are drawstop objects. They forward key presses from one manual to other manuals/keys. They have the following additional attributes:

listitem.para: (boolean, required) If true, this coupler decouples the manual from the stops (turn it into a floating manual).
(integer manual number, required if not a unison off coupler) manual to forward key presses to.
(integer -24 - 24, required if not a unison off coupler) specifies the keyboard shift between source and destination manual in terms of absolute MIDI note numbers
(boolean, required if not a unison off/melody/bass coupler) Triggers further inter-manual coupler with a destination key shift of zero.
(boolean, required if not a unison off/melody/bass coupler) Triggers further inter-manual coupler with a destination key shift greater than zero.
(boolean, required if not a unison off/melody/bass coupler) Triggers further inter-manual coupler with a destination key shift less than zero.
(boolean, required if not a unison off/melody/bass coupler) Triggers further intra-manual coupler with a destination key shift greater than zero.
(boolean, required if not a unison off/melody/bass coupler) Triggers further intra-manual coupler with a destination key shift less than zero.
(enumeration, default: Normal) Type of the coupler: Normal, Bass or Melody.
(integer 0 - 127, default: 0) first MIDI note number to forward
(integer 0 - 127, default: 0) number of keys to forward starting with FirstMIDINoteNumber.

sect1.title: Switch objects
sect1.para: A switch object is a drawstop objects without any additional attributes. It can be used, for example, to trigger stop action noises and key action noises. See the Demo organ and the Kalvtrask organ for examples of its use.

sect1.title: Rank objects
sect1.para: A rank represents a row of pipes. It can be either be part of a stop section or appear in its own section.

listitem.para: (string, required) Name of the rank. The name may be presented to the user in lists too, therefore it should be descriptive.
(integer 0 - 256, if the rank is part of a stop section, the default value is derived from the associated manuals. Otherwise required) MIDI note number of the first pipe
(integer 1 - 192, required) Number of pipes in this rank
(float 0 - 1000, default: 100) Linear amplitude scale factor applied to the whole rank. 100 means no change.
(float -120 - 40, default: 0) Amplitude scale factor in dB applied to the whole rank. 0 means no change.
(float -1800 - 1800, default: 0) Retune the rank by the specified number of cents.
(integer 0 - 10000, default: 0) Delay introduced by the tracker for that rank.
(float 1 - 1024, default: 8) Harmonic number (= 64 / rank size), eg. 2 2/3 => 64 / (2 2/3) = 24. The harmonic number is used determining alternative tunings.
(float -1800 - 1800, default: 0) Correction factor in cent for the pitch of the rank. This setting is used for retuning to other temperaments.
(integer 1 - number of windchests, required) specify the windchest on which the pipes of the are placed.
(boolean, default inherited from the Windchest section) If true, the samples are played as is (without any loop/release handling).
(boolean, default inherited from the Windchest section). If true, releases are played independently of the attacks.
If HasIndependentRelease is true then Percussive must also be set to true.
(float 0 - 1000, default: 100) Linear amplitude scale factor at low velocity applied to the whole rank. 100 means no change.
(float 0 - 1000, default: 100) Linear amplitude scale factor at high velocity applied to the whole rank. 100 means no change.
(boolean, default: true) Determines if the rank will be retuned according to the current temperament. Retuning should be only disabled for sound effects.

sect1.para: A rank section contains the attributes of each of its pipes too. The attributes of each pipe are prefixed with Pipe999 (number starting with 1). The supported attributes are:

listitem.para: (string, required) Relative path to the sample WAV file of the first attack. It may be listed as REF:aa:bb:cc too. In that case, it means that this pipe is borrowed from manual aa, first rank of stop bb, the pipe cc. It may contain DUMMY, which defines a non-sounding placeholder.
(boolean, default: rank Percussive setting) If true, the samples are played as is (without any loop/release handling)
(boolean, default: rank HasIndependentRelease setting). If true, releases are played independently of attacks in this pipe.
If HasIndependentRelease is true then Pipe999Percussive must be also true and Pipe999ReleaseCount must be greater than 0.
(float 0 - 1000, default: 100) Linear amplitude scale factor applied to the pipe (in addition to the organ/windchest/rank factor). 100 means no change.
(float -120 - 40, default: 0) Amplitude scale factor in dB applied to the pipe (in addition to the organ/windchest/rank factor). 0 means no change.
(float -1800 - 1800, default: 0) Retune this pipe the specified number of cents (in addition to the organ/windchest/rank factor).
(integer 0 - 10000, default: 0) Delay introduced by the tracker for that pipe.
(boolean, default: reverse of percussive setting) If true, the release part is loaded from the first attack sample.
(integer 0 - 127, default: 0) minimum velocity to use this attack sample.
(integer -1 - 100000, default: -1) maximum time since the last release of the key to be able to use that attack. -1 means infinite.

(integer -1 - 1, default: -1) 1 means, that it is played, if the associated wave-based tremulant is on. 0 means, that it is played, if the associated wave-based tremulant is off. -1 means, that it is not affected by a wave-based tremulant.
(integer -1 - 100000, default: -1) Up to this time value in ms, the release sample is chosen. -1 means infinite.
(integer 0 - 158760000, default: 0) Allows to override the start of the sample. This option is specified in samples.
(integer -1 - 158760000, default: -1) Allows to override the cue point for the release. -1 means use from the wave file. This option is specified in samples.
(integer -1 - 158760000, default: -1) Allows to override the end of the release. -1 means play till the end of the wav. This option is specified in samples.
(integer 0 - 100, default: 0) Allows to override the loops in the WAV file. 0 means use loops from the wave file.
(integer 0 - 158760000, default: 0) Start sample of the loop. The value must be within the WAV file. This option is specified in samples.
(integer Pipe999Loop999Start + 1 - 158760000, required if Pipe999LoopCount is not zero) End sample of the loop. The value must be within the WAV file. This option is specified in samples.
(float 1 - 1024, default: rank harmonic number) Harmonic number (= 64 / rank size), eg. 2 2/3 => 64 / (2 2/3) = 24.

(integer -1 - 127, default: -1) If -1, use pitch information from the Pipe999 sample, else override the information in the sample with this MIDI note number (Pipe999MIDIPitchFraction is used for specifying the fraction). Specifying the MIDI note number also resets the pitch fraction in the sample to 0 unless Pipe999MIDIPitchFraction is also specified.

(float 0 - 100, default: -1) If -1, use pitch information from the Pipe999 sample, else override the information in the sample with this value. Describes the actual existing pitch fraction in cent over the normal (440hz equal) tone of the midi key specified in the sample or in the Pipe999MIDIKeyNumber. This setting (together with Pipe999MIDIKeyNumber) is used when retuning to other temperaments.

(float -1800 - 1800, default: 0) Correction factor in cent for the pitch specified in the sample in addition to PitchCorrection of the whole organ, of the windchest and of the rank. This setting is used to adjust tuning while in other temperaments (than original). A positive value raise the pitch, a negative value lowers the pitch.
(boolean, default: rank setting) Determines if the pipe will be retuned according to the current temperament. Retuning should be only disabled for sound effects.
(integer 1 - number of windchests, default: rank windchest) specify the windchest, on which this pipe is placed.
(float 0 - 1000, default: corresponding rank setting) Linear amplitude scale factor at low velocity applied to the pipe. 100 means no change.
(float 0 - 1000, default: corresponding rank setting) Linear amplitude scale factor at high velocity applied to the pipe. 100 means no change.
(integer 0 - 100, default: 0) Number of additional attack samples
(string, required) Relative path to the sample WAV file.
(boolean, default: reverse of percussive setting) If true, the release part is loaded.
(integer 0 - 127, default: 0) minimum velocity to use this attack sample.
(integer -1 - 100000, default: -1) maximum time since the last release of the key to be able to use that attack. -1 means infinite.

(integer -1 - 1, default: -1) 1 means, that it is played, if the associated wave-based tremulant is on. 0 means, that it is played, if the associated wave-based tremulant is off. -1 means, that it not affected by a wave-based tremulant.
(integer -1 - 100000, default: -1) Up to this time value in ms, the release sample is chosen. -1 means infinite.
(integer 0 - 158760000, default: 0) Allows to override the start of the sample. This option is specified in samples.
(integer -1 - 158760000, default: -1) Allows to override the cue point for the release. -1 means use from the wave file. This option is specified in samples.
(integer -1 - 158760000, default: -1) Allows to override the end of the release. -1 means play till the end of the wav. This option is specified in samples.
(integer 0 - 100, default: 0) Allows to override the loops in the WAV file. 0 means use loops from the wave file.
(integer 0 - 158760000, default: 0) Start sample of the loop. The value must be within the WAV file. This option is specified in samples.
(integer Pipe999Loop999Start + 1 - 158760000, required if Pipe999LoopCount is not zero) End sample of the loop. The value must be within the WAV file. This option is specified in samples.
(integer 0 - 100, default: 0) Number of additional release samples
(string, required) Relative path to the sample WAV file.

(integer -1 - 1, default: -1) 1 means, that it is played, if the associated wave-based tremulant is on. 0 means, that it is played, if the associated wave-based tremulant is off. -1 means, that it not affected by a wave-based tremulant.
(integer -1 - 100000, default: -1) Up to this time value in ms, the release sample is chosen. -1 means infinite.
(integer -1 - 158760000, default: -1) Allows to override the cue point for the release. -1 means use from the wave file.
(integer -1 - 158760000, default: -1) Allows to override the end of the release. -1 means play till the end of the wav. This option is specified in samples.

(integer 0 - 3000, default: 0) Crossfade length in ms between loop end and loop start for all loops loaded from the file specified in the Pipe999 parameter. A cross fade requires enough samples before the start of the loop.
This parameter is not inherited by loops loaded from additional attack files specified in the Pipe999Attack999 parameters

(integer 0 - 3000, default: 0) Crossfade length in ms between loop end and loop start for all loops loaded from the file Pipe999Attack999. A cross fade requires enough samples before the start of the loop.
(integer 0 - 3000, default: 0). 0 means automatic selection.
Crossfade length in ms between loop and the release loaded from the file specified in the Pipe999 parameter or between different attack samples if Pipe999AttackCount > 0.

This parameter is not inherited by the releases loaded from additional attack and release files specified in the Pipe999Attack999 and Pipe999Release999 parameters that should be specified with the Pipe999Attack999ReleaseCrossfadeLength and Pipe999Release999ReleaseCrossfadeLength parameters.
(integer 0 - 3000, default: 0). 0 means automatic selection.
Crossfade length in ms between loop and the release loaded from the file specified in the Pipe999Attack999 parameter.
(integer 0 - 3000, default: 0). 0 means automatic selection.
Crossfade length in ms between loop and the release loaded from the file specified in the Pipe999Release999 parameter.

sect1.title: Stop objects
sect1.para: Stop objects are drawstop objects. A stop consists of a number of ranks. If the number of ranks is set to zero, the stop contains one rank, which is defined in the stop section - else it references a list of ranks. Only the accessible pipes can be triggered from the manual. A stop has the following additions attributes:

listitem.para: (integer 0 - 999, default: 0) Number of referenced ranks. If zero, one rank definition is included in the stop section. The lists of references is specified via the Rank999... settings.
(integer 1 - 128, required) The key number on the manual of the first accessible pipe.
(integer 1 - 192, required) Number of pipes, that are playable from the manual starting from the first accessible pipe.
(integer 1 - 192, required if NumberOfRanks=0) The number of the first pipe accessible from the manual. If NumberOfRanks is not 0, this setting is not necessary.
(integer 0 - rank count specified in the organ section, required) Reference to a rank from the organ section.
(integer 1 - number of pipes in the rank, default: 1) Number of first mapped pipe from the rank
(integer 0 - remaining number of pipes in the rank, default: remaining number of pipes in the rank) Number of pipes mapped from the rank.
(integer 1 - NumberOfAccessiblePipes, default: 1) Key number offset (starting with FirstAccessiblePipeLogicalKeyNumber) for the pipe referenced by Rank999FirstPipeNumber.

sect1.title: Pushbutton objects
sect1.para: Pushbuttons are buttons without any state. It is displayed as a piston.

sect1.title: Piston objects
sect1.para: A piston is a pushbutton which triggers other elements. It contains the following additional attributes:

listitem.para: (string, required) Type of the element to trigger. Value can be STOP, COUPLER, SWITCH or TREMULANT.
(integer first manual index - last manual index, required for stops and coupler) The manual, to which the referenced object belongs.
(integer, required) Determines the number of the object. Depending on the object it must be a valid stop/coupler/switch number on the referenced manual or a valid global tremulant number.

sect1.title: Tremulant objects
sect1.para: Tremulants are drawstop objects with the following additional attributes:

listitem.para: (enumeration, default: Synth) Type of the tremulant. Valid values are: Synth (synthesized tremulant) and Wave (tremulant based on different wave samples).

sect1.para: Synthesized tremulants have the following attributes:

listitem.para: (integer 32 - 44100, required) Period of the tremulant in ms
(integer 1 - 100, required) Determines the startup time of the tremulant.
(integer 1 - 100, required) Determines the stop time of the tremulant.
(integer 1 - 100, required) Determines, how much the volume will be changed.

sect1.title: Windchest objects
sect1.para: Windchest objects represent a windchest on which pipes of ranks are placed. It has the following attributes:

listitem.para: (string, default: implementation dependent) Display name of this windchest
(integer 0 - enclosure count, required) Number of enclosures, which influence this windchest. The list is specified by the Enclosure999 entries in the windchest section.
(integer 0 - tremulant count, required) Number of tremulants, which influence this windchest. The list is specified by the Tremulant999 entries in the windchest section.
(integer 1 - enclosure count, required) Number of an enclosure, which influences this windchest.
(integer 1 - tremulant count, required) Number of a tremulant, which influences this windchest.
(float 0 - 1000, default: 100) Linear amplitude scale factor in percents applied to the windchest. It is multilied to the AmplitudeLevel value of the Organ section. 100 means no change.
(float -120 - 40, default: 0) Amplitude scale factor in dB applied to the windchest. It is added to the Gain value of the Organ section. 0 means no change.

(float -1800 - 1800, default: 0) Retune the windchest by the specified number of cents. It is added to the PitchTuning value of the Organ section. 0 means no change. This setting is used only for the original temperament.

(float -1800 - 1800, default: 0) Correction factor in cent for the pitch of the windchest. It is added to the PitchTuning value of the Organ section. 0 means no change. This setting is used for retuning to other temperaments.
(integer 0 - 10000, default: 0) Delay in miliseconds introduced by the tracker applied to the windchest. It is added to the TrackerDelay value of the Organ section.
(boolean, default inherited from the Organ section) If true, the samples are played as is (without any loop/release handling).
(boolean, default inherited from the Organ section). If true, releases are played independently of the attacks.
If HasIndependentRelease is true then Percussive must also be set to true.

sect1.title: Crescendo objects
sect1.para: Crescendo objects represent a crescendo bank. The number of crescendo banks are always 4: from 0 to 3

listitem.para: (boolean, default: true) The crescendo mode: how the crescendo operates with stops enabled by the user.
true - Override mode
true - Add mode
The difference between these modes are described at Crescendo operational modes

sect1.title: Additional panels (old format)
sect1.para: It is possible to define additional panels. The section is called Panel999 with a number starting from 001. All panels use the same layout engine as the main panel, therefore the section includes all display metrics attributes. Additionally it includes the following attributes:

listitem.para: (string, required) Name of the panel
(string, default: empty) If not empty, place it in the submenu with the specified name, else directly in the panel menu.
(integer 1 - number of defined manuals) number of manuals to display on this panel
(boolean, required) Includes a manual displayed as pedal
(integer 0 - 999, default: 0) Number of setter elements on the panel. The section of the GUI definitions are called Panel999SetterElement999.
(integer 0 - number of defined enclosures, required) Number of enclosures on the panel. The section of the enclosures GUI definitions are called Panel999Enclosure999.
(valid enclosure number, required) Reference to the enclosure on the main panel.
(integer 0 - number of defined tremulants, required) Number of tremulant on the panel. The section of the tremulants GUI definitions are called Panel999Tremulant999.
(valid tremulant number, required) Reference to the tremulant on the main panel.
(integer 0 - number of defined reversible pistons, required) Number of reversible pistons on the panel. The section of the reversible pistons GUI definitions are called Panel999ReversiblePiston999.
(valid reversible piston number, required) Reference to the reversible piston on the main panel.
(integer 0 - number of defined switches, default: 0) Number of switches on the panel. The section of the switches GUI definitions are called Panel999Switchn999.
(valid switch number, required) Reference to the switch on the main panel.
(integer 0 - number of defined generals, required) Number of generals on the panel. The section of the generals GUI definitions are called Panel999General999.
(valid general number, required) Reference to the general on the main panel.

(integer 0 - number of defined divisional couplers, required) Number of divisional couplers on the panel. The section of the divisional coupler GUI definitions are called Panel999DivisionalCoupler999.
(valid divisional coupler number, required) Reference to the divisional coupler on the main panel.
(valid manual number, required) Number of the manual to use a specified manual on the panel.
(integer 0 - 999, required) Number of stops on the panel. The section of the stops GUI definitions are called Panel999Stop999.
(valid manual number, required) Reference to the manual of the stop on the main panel.
(valid stop number, required) Reference to the stop on the main panel.
(integer 0 - 999, required) Number of couplers on the panel. The section of the couplers GUI definitions are called Panel999Coupler999.
(valid manual number, required) Reference to the manual of the coupler on the main panel.
(valid coupler number, required) Reference to the divisional on the main panel.
(integer 0 - 999, required) Number of divisionals on the panel. The section of the divisionals GUI definitions are called Panel999Divisional999.
(valid manual number, required) Reference to the manual of the divisional on the main panel.
(valid divisional number, required) Reference to the divisional on the main panel.
(integer 0 - 999, required) Number of labels on the panel. The section of the label GUI definitions are called Panel999Label999.
(integer 0 - 999, default: 0) Number of images on the panel. The section of the image GUI definitions are called Panel999Image999.

sect1.title: Panels (new format)
sect1.para: The section is called Panel999. Panel000 is the main panel. Additional panels start with number 001. The section includes the display metrics. Additionally it includes the following attributes:

listitem.para: (string, required for non-main panels) Name of the panel
(string, default: empty, only for non-main panels) If not empty, place it in the submenu with the specified name, else directly in the panel menu.
(boolean, required) Includes a manual displayed as pedal
(integer 0 - 999, default: 0) Number of images on the panel. The section of the image GUI definitions are called Panel999Image999.
(integer 0 - 999, required for the main panel, default 0 for any other panel) Number of elements on the panel. The section of the GUI elements are called Panel999Element999.

sect1.title: GUI elements
sect1.para: The attribute Type can be one of the following values:

listitem.para: The section contains the GUI attributes of a divisional. Additionally it includes the following attributes:
(valid manual number, required) Number of the manual.
(valid divisional number, required) Number of the divisional on the manual.
The section contains the GUI attributes of a coupler. Additionally it includes the following attributes:
(valid manual number, required) Number of the manual.
(valid coupler number, required) Number of the coupler on the manual.
The section contains the GUI attributes of a stop. Additionally it includes the following attributes:

sect1.title: General information
sect1.para: An organ package is a ZIP file using only the STORED compression [= compression level 0] with the extension orgue. It may use the ZIP64 extensions - no other extensions are allowed. It is possible to store file names containing directories.
The ID of an organ package is its SHA1 sum with all letter converted to upper case.
Each organ package must contain an index file named organindex.ini. This file lists all contained organs as well as any other organ package they might depend on.
Referenced files are only loaded from the organ package - not from the file system. If a file is missing in the main organ package, it will search Dependency001, then Dependency002 and so on.
Use wavpack to compress samples. Use PNG for lossless compression of images.

sect1.title: Index file specification
sect1.para: It has the same syntax rules as an organ definition file. The General section has the following elements:

listitem.para: (string, required) Name of the organ package
(integer 0 - 100, required) Number of organs installed by this package. The organs are defined in a section named Organ999.
(integer 0 - 100, default: 0) Number of organs packages required by this organ package. The dependencies are defined in a section named Dependency999.

sect1.title: Dependency section
sect1.para: The section has the following elements:

listitem.para: (string, required) ID of the package file, that should be searched for missing files.
(string, required) Name of the package file.

sect1.title: Organ section
sect1.para: This section has the following elements:

listitem.para: (string, required) Filename of organ definition file in the organ package.
(string, required) Name of the organ/church. This setting must match the organ definition file.
(string, required) informational text displayed in the property dialog. This setting must match the organ definition file.

appendix.title: Short octave
appendix.simpara: GrandOrgue can use three different methods to make a short octave keyboard:

listitem.simpara: This is the build scheme:
The keyboard defines e.g. 45 keys (full compass: 49)
The first accessible key on the physical keyboard is low E
The first sample (Pipe001) refers to low C (read: press low E, hear low C)
The second sample (Pipe002) refers to low F (read: press low F, hear low F)
The third sample (Pipe003) refers to low D (read: press low F#, hear low D)
The fourth sample (Pipe004) refers to low G (read: press low G, hear low G)
The fifth sample (Pipe005) refers to low E (read: press low G#, hear low E)
From the sixth sample and upwards, the keyboard layout is "normal"

listitem.para:
The pipe layout to the keys being hardwired, many useful features which expect 12-note octaves are broken in the low octave:
Octave and suboctave couplers (Even if this feature is unlikely when reproducing old organs) Bass and melody couplers Tuning to other temperaments
listitem.simpara: This method should be considered as legacy and used only for backward compatibility with Hauptwerk™ version 1 sample sets. The preferred method for designing a short octave keyboard is through a key mapping (see MIDIKey999) and below.

simpara.emphasis: MIDI setting: 9x Note short octave at low key

listitem.simpara: Use this setting to simulate a short octave keyboard when the Organ Definition File only provides a full compass keyboard. GrandOrgue renders sound as if the keyboard were fitted with a short octave, but the visual feedback is that of a full compass keyboard (e.g. press low E and the keyboard image in the GUI displays a depressed low C).

listitem.para:
This is the build scheme:
The keyboard defines e.g. 49 keys, full compass The first accessible key on the physical keyboard is low C Pipe999 entries refer to all pipes starting a low C, as usual Configure the GUI:
DisplayKeys=45 Display only 45 keys
DisplayFirstNote=40 The fist displayed key is low E
Add MIDIKey999 entries.
MIDIKey036=0 Disable low C
MIDIKey037=0 Disable low C#
MIDIKey038=0 Disable low D
MIDIKey039=0 Disable low D#
MIDIKey040=36 Map physical low E to sound low C
MIDIKey041=41 Map physical low F to sound low F
MIDIKey042=38 Map physical low F# to sound low D
MIDIKey043=43 Map physical low G to sound low G
MIDIKey044=40 Map physical low G# to sound low E
MIDIKey045=45 Map physical low A to sound low A. From this key up to the top end of the keyboard, the mapping is usual and can be omitted.
Add DisplayKey999 entries to tie GUI keys to MIDI note numbers:
DisplayKey001=36 1st Key is depressed in the GUI when MIDI note 36 (low C) is received
DisplayKey002=41 2nd Key is depressed in the GUI when MIDI note 41 (low F) is received
DisplayKey003=38 3rd Key is depressed in the GUI when MIDI note 38 (low D) is received
DisplayKey004=43 4th Key is depressed in the GUI when MIDI note 43 (low G) is received
DisplayKey005=40 5th Key is depressed in the GUI when MIDI note 40 (low E) is received
DisplayKey006=45 6th Key is depressed in the GUI when MIDI note 45 (low A) is received. From this key up to the top end of the keyboard, the mapping is usual and can be omitted.
When sampling a real-world organ, missing samples in the low octave need to be generated to get a complete low octave. If this is not done, holes will appear in the low octave if the keyboard is converted to full compass using the 9x Note without map MIDI setting.
